Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineering Tools for Disease Diagnostics and Treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global health security (GHS) is a worldwide priority that deals with prevention, detection, treatment and control of diseases. GHS can only be realized through interdisciplinary collaborations in which engineering endeavors play a vital role. This three year Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at Washington State University (WSU), Engineering Tools for Disease Diagnostics and Treatment, will provide research opportunities to a diverse cohort of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups with limited access to research facilities, who will explore an array of significant societal problems that lie on the interface of health science and engineering. The proposed research projects are focused on designing better tools to predict and treat bacterial infections, cardiac diseases, osteoarthritis, diabetes, ergonomic problems and cancers. These projects address an array of pressing health challenges that face not only the United States, but the entire world.

Washington State University (WSU) will host 9 undergraduate students over 9.5 summer weeks to design, fabricate and utilize engineering tools to diagnose and treat diverse ubiquitous and emerging diseases. The program has six goals in research and technical as well as professional development. These are to: 1) provide scholars with hands-on research activities focused on developing engineering tools for disease diagnostics and treatment, 2) increase REU scholars' awareness of emerging grand challenges to global health, 3) strengthen the academic credentials and technical skills of participating scholars, 4) clarify career paths for REU scholars, 5) diversify the pool of talented students interested in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields, and 6) broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. To achieve program goals, students will participate in mentored, hypothesis-based, research projects that address health problems with real-world relevance. These research experiences will be intertwined with a set of technical seminars that expose students to cutting edge, engineering research tools used in disease diagnosis and treatment. Activities such as entrepreneurship and proposal writing will be used to develop students' professional skills. REU program findings will be disseminated through poster and oral presentations at local and national meetings as well as through peer-reviewed publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of 9.5 weeks during 3 summers from 2017 to 2019, a diverse cohort, e.g., multi-ethnic and multi-gendered, of engineers and scientists were invited into the laboratories of research faculty in the Voiland School of Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering at Washington State University. All 38 of these students participated in hands-on research using engineering tools to help address global health challenges. Our program was designed to increase our scholars' awareness of existing and emerging health challenges, to strengthen their academic credentials and technical skills, to help clarify their career paths enabling them to advance quickly in their chosen professions, and to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities and veterans in STEM-based careers.

The cohort of 35 students who participated in our REU program consisted of 24 female and 11 male students with the 3 additional students (all male who had served in the military) supported by a supplemental REU targeted to recruiting veterans. This was a step towards training students who are minorities and/or veterans into STEM to diversify STEM talent.

Our REU scholars participated in mentored research experiences aimed at engaging them in collaborative teams working on the design, development and application of engineering tools to diagnose or treat diseases. Projects were designed to have a scope that could be completed by undergraduate scholars within the 9.5 Summer weeks of the program as well as being tailored by faculty mentors to accommodate sophomore- and junior-year engineers and scientists with limited theoretical, scientific or experimental backgrounds. In addition, all projects had a degree of flexibility which would allow our scholars to discover their strengths and interests, providing them with room to grow in their discipline. Finally, almost all of the proposed

projects involved hands-on wet-lab bio-experiments and several also included a theoretical or modeling component. The research experiences were intertwined with a series of technical seminars and brown-bag lunch seminars targeted at exposing scholars to the breadth of engineering tools used in addressing variable health challenges.

As part of their summer education, all of our REU students participated in workshops, weekly seminars and training sessions including safety and biosafety training, responsible conduct of science presentations including how to keep a laboratory notebook, human subjects in research training, abstract writing and poster preparation. All students presented the research component of their Summer work during the last week of the REU in both a 15-minute technical slide presentation to the core REU cohort and their faculty mentors as well as a poster presentation to the larger WSU-REU program.

All of our REU students and a few additional undergraduates from their labs participated in trips to various sites to increase their awareness of different career paths available to them. These included a trip to the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory EMSL laboratory in Richland WA, Shriners Children?s' Hospital and St. Luke's Hospital Gait Laboratory in Spokane WA, and the Manhattan Project B Reactor Site Tour at the Hanford Site in Richland WA. A final component of our program was a set of social activities beginning with an orientation in collaboration with Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR)/WSU. In addition, the Voiland School of Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering (VSCEB) sponsored a welcoming barbeque (BBQ), an end-of-program breakfast, and a challenge course at WSU?s recreation center (REC) during the first weekend of the program.

In the time that has passed since they completed their Summer REU at WSU, most of our students have continued on to graduate engineering programs or professional schools, primarily medical schools. Along the way, several have published manuscripts in technical journals or have presented papers or posters based on their research here at WSU.
